image.altText: Man sits with his tea on his balcony

items.synopsis: Steve Klinge, who lives with schizophrenia, spends most days alone in his apartment in the small town of Goomeri. He's one of the many Queenslanders who have been displaced by the state's housing crisis.

title.children: After half a dozen moves, Steve has finally found a home he can afford – but it's 150km from everything he knows

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair wearing a white top and suit jacket speaking into media microphones

items.synopsis: A fresh inquiry is launched into Queensland's forensics DNA lab to investigate concerns about an automated DNA extraction method.

title.children: New inquiry launched into Queensland forensic lab bungles amid ongoing concerns

image.altText: Peter Dutton speaks into microphones at a media conference standing in front of Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price.

items.synopsis: If the Voice isn't the solution, as Peter Dutton argues, what is? How will Australia tackle Indigenous disadvantage if the majority vote No? Given the polls all suggest a No vote is the most likely outcome, the answer is surprisingly unclear, writes David Speers.

title.children: Dutton has finally settled on an alternative solution to the Voice: Jacinta Nampijinpa Price

image.altText: A woman holds a toddler on her hip and looks at the camera with a neutral expression while standing in a shaded backyard.

items.synopsis: Warana mum Vanessa Morrow permanently withdrew her two sons from a Sunshine Coast early learning centre after receiving messages "almost every day" asking parents to "assist in maintaining compliant ratios".

title.children: Parents like Vanessa are pulling out of childcare after 'constant' requests to keep kids home

image.altText: A group of people unload sandbags from a trailer onto the ground.

items.synopsis: Authorities say about 130 properties could be impacted with "above floor inundation" as the scale of flooding surpasses what had been planned for.

title.children: Gippsland residents evacuate as homes and farms flood, while snow falls on Victorian Alps

image.altText: A coin with King Charles III

items.synopsis: For the first time in seven decades, Australian currency will feature a new monarch. The new effigy of King Charles III faces the opposite direction on coins to his mother and also sees the king without a crown.

title.children: Royal Australian Mint unveils new effigy of King Charles III set to appear on coins before Christmas

image.altText: Sydney flight board with airline cancellations listed

items.synopsis: Winds gusts up to 90 kilometres per hour disrupted flights at Sydney's domestic airport, as a severe weather warning is issued.

title.children: Strong winds force cancellation of almost 100 flights in and out of Sydney

image.altText: A woman with glasses sitting in a kitchen

items.synopsis: A Stolen Generation survivor reveals the heartbreak her family faces with her grandchildren in state care, as a report reveals alarming rates of South Australian Aboriginal children being removed.

title.children: Louise was days old when she was taken into care — experiences like hers are still happening

image.altText: Lili stands near a beach wearing a City to Surf medal and running shorts and top.

items.synopsis: Nowadays Lili Mooney loves going running, but as a teenager with an eating disorder her relationship with exercise was not always easy.

title.children: As a teen with an eating disorder, one of Lili's symptoms was compulsive exercise

image.altText: Man sits on wooden bench and smiles at camera.

items.synopsis: North Queensland doctors say the number of patients seeking voluntary assisted dying consultations has been underestimated and they need more practitioners to meet demand.

title.children: Dr Claus Bader helps Queenslanders legally end their lives. He's been inundated with enquiries

image.altText: Rueben Berg smiles as he looks up in a bushland setting.

items.synopsis: As Australia's referendum vote on an Indigenous Voice to Parliament looms, the idea of treaties has been pulled into the debate. But the reality is — Voice referendum or not — most Australian states are already moving towards state-based treaties.

title.children: The Voice to Parliament debate often mentions treaties — most states are already doing it

image.altText: Voice blog graphic October 5

items.synopsis: Follow our live blog for the latest news in the lead-up to voting in the referendum on October 14.

title.children: Latest updates as pre-polling for Voice to Parliament referendum is underway

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A new video from Indigenous rapper Senator Briggs takes aim at misinformation on the Voice. It's racked up over a million views after being shared by Jason Mamoa and Taika Waititi on Instagram.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Senator Briggs asks 'Have you Googled it'?

children.content: A new video from Indigenous rapper
Senator Briggs
takes aim at misinformation on the Voice.
It's racked up over a million views after being shared by
Jason Mamoa
and
Taika Waititi
on Instagram.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Federal Labor senator for Victoria Jana Stewart says she's confident people will get behind the proposed Voice to Parliament, as the last leg of campaigning gets underway. There is just over a week until the referendum on October 14, but AEC data shows more than 900,000 Australians have already voted. Senator Stewart says polls that have the No campaign leading don't reflect what people tell her on the ground. "Lots of people as they are going past, they are saying to me 'I am already saying yes'. "There are people who are saying to me as they are walking in, it's really simple and they'll say, 'I'm voting yes but I'm not telling my friends because it has been really horrible'."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Labor senator Jana Stewart is confident people will get behind the Voice

children.content: Federal Labor senator for Victoria Jana
Stewart
says she's confident people will get behind the proposed Voice to Parliament, as the last leg of campaigning gets underway.
There is just over a week until the referendum on October 14, but
AEC
data shows more than
900,000 Australians
have already voted.
Senator Stewart says polls that have the No campaign leading don't reflect what people tell her on the ground.
"Lots of people as they are going past, they are saying to me 'I am already saying yes'.
"There are people who are saying to me as they are walking in, it's really simple and they'll say, 'I'm voting yes but I'm not telling my friends because it has been really horrible'."

props.alt: A woman wearing her hair in a bun smiling wearing a blazer.

children.content: Jana Stewart says she is confident people will get behind the Voice.
(ABC News: Ross Nerdal)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: As you may have heard, a referendum needs a double majority to pass. This is one of its key differences from a federal election. This means that two things will need to happen: A majority of Australian voters in a referendum need to support the proposed change And: Majority of voters in a majority of Australia's six states need to support the change To read more about this follow the link below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: A double majority will be needed for the Voice to pass.  What does this mean?

featuredLink.title: A double majority is needed for the Voice referendum to pass. What does that mean and how does it work?

children.content: As you may have heard, a referendum needs a
double majority
to pass.
This is one of its key differences from a
federal election.
This means that two things will need to happen:
A majority of Australian voters in a referendum need to support the proposed change
And:
Majority of voters in a majority of Australia's six states need to support the change

props.alt: Two maps of Australia side by side.

children.content: Votes from the ACT, the NT and other external territories count towards the national majority only.
(Supplied: Parliamentary Education Office)
To read more about this follow the link below:

image.altText: Andrew Giles speaks outside Parliament House

items.synopsis: The federal government is overhauling the protection visa system, saying people traffickers and false claims have "clogged" the system, leaving refugees waiting for longer.

title.children: 'False' asylum applicants staying up to 11 years on temporary visas before cases resolved

image.altText: A woman with grey and black hair, wearing round glasses, stands in front of an out-of-focus lake

items.synopsis: When journalist Sheridan Jobbins started searching for a piece of unclaimed family land, she uncovered a colonial massacre in her family name.

title.children: Sheridan Jobbins was looking for a piece of land. What she found was an Indigenous massacre

image.altText: A man looks past the camera.

items.synopsis: How are people surviving in a country where inflation is running at more than 100 per cent? Foreign Correspondent goes to Buenos Aires to find out.

title.children: 'They are voting for the executioner': Argentina's man with a plan so radical over 100 economists have trashed it

image.altText: Anthony Albanese wearing a black hoodie with the "yes" logo on the front.

items.synopsis: An oft-repeated claim during the Voice campaign has been that a young Indigenous man is more likely to go to jail than university. Is that correct?

title.children: We fact checked Anthony Albanese on young Indigenous men in jail or university. Here's what we found

image.altText: Gianni Infantino looks to one side

items.synopsis: The 2030 Men's FIFA World Cup will be staged in six different countries, including the surprise addition of South America, to mark the tournament's centenary.

title.children: 'Horrendous' three-continent World Cup set for 2030

image.altText: two young aboriginal men smiling

items.synopsis: Australians everywhere are picking up their phones and contributing to the debate over the upcoming Voice to Parliament referendum. For First Nations creators, it's taking a toll on their mental health.

title.children: TikTokers targeted with abuse, personal attacks over Voice videos

image.altText: An Indigenous woman stacks shelves at a grocery store smiles at camera

items.synopsis: A new megastore creates career opportunities for First Nations locals in Queensland's north-west, while dramatically cutting grocery bills for its community.

title.children: This remote community was paying $17 a kilo for tomatoes, but an Indigenous-owned supermarket has slashed prices

image.altText: Two newly built tiny houses in Bunbury

items.synopsis: A tiny homes trial in WA that helped 13 people access housing — including grandmother Dianne — is deemed a "fantastic" success, and a Queensland professor says it could help in other Australian towns.

title.children: A tiny home got Dianne off the streets — and an expert says the small dwellings could help ease the housing crisis

image.altText: A young Aboriginal man leans forward on the white rodeo arena railing and stares at the camera. He wears green prison garb.

items.synopsis: This week, the 19-year-old will ride a bucking bull at the Alice Springs rodeo as part of a program to reduce crime and reconnect young offenders with community.

title.children: Jefferson Woodie can't change his criminal past but he has plans to change his future

image.altText: Two teenagers with Rubik's Cubes

items.synopsis: Charlie Eggins and Toby Seufert are two of the fastest Rubik's cube solvers in the world — and here are the methods they use.

title.children: These 14-year-olds are now the fastest Rubik's cube solvers in the world

image.altText: David Warner on his knees

items.synopsis: Despite there being more ODIs played than ever before, the men's Cricket World Cup in India gets underway with questions again being raised over the future of the format and its place in an increasingly crowded cricket calendar.

title.children: 'Maybe there won't be another World Cup': Questions grow as cricket's 50-over format struggles in a crowded calendar

image.altText: a man infront of a granny flat

items.synopsis: New data released by CoreLogic shows the rental crisis is getting worse. With fewer affordable rentals on the market, more people are turning to granny flats, share houses and house-sitting to put a roof over their heads.

title.children: The granny flat is no longer just for the older generation, as struggling renters move back home with parents

image.altText: The exterior of the Don Dale Youth Detention Centre, with barbed wire in the foreground.

items.synopsis: The teenager has pleaded not guilty to two aggravated assault charges and two charges related to assaulting workers in relation to the incident, claiming Don Dale officers had acted unlawfully.

title.children: Don Dale officer accused of bullying, withholding food in former detainee assault case

image.altText: Children’s Court President Hylton Quail

items.synopsis: The case of a teenage boy in detention shines a light on how some of WA's most vulnerable children are missing out on support for foetal alcohol spectrum disorder due to a crippling shortage of child health professionals.

title.children: 'Beggars belief': Delays testing vulnerable kids for FASD condemned by Children's Court president

image.altText: tesla

items.synopsis: US tech stocks rally overnight, ASX tipped to open higher — follow live.

title.children: US tech stocks rally overnight, ASX tipped to open higher

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The futures were correct. After 30 minutes of trading this morning, the ASX200 index is up 18 points (+0.3%).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens higher

children.content: The futures were correct.
After 30 minutes of trading this morning, the ASX200 index is up 18 points (+0.3%).

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australia's dollar fell below 62 US cents yesterday. My colleague Kirsten Aiken spoke to NAB's senior foreign exchange strategist, Rodrigo Catril, last night about what's happening. Mr Catril says he wouldn't be surprised if the dollar tumbles further in the near term. You catch his analysis here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Aussie dollar to keep weakening?

featuredLink.title: Aussie dollar set to fall further, says NAB senior FX strategist | The Business | ABC News

children.content: Australia's dollar fell below 62 US cents yesterday.
My colleague Kirsten Aiken spoke to
NAB's senior foreign exchange strategist
Rodrigo Catril
, last night about what's happening.
Mr Catril says he wouldn't be surprised if the dollar tumbles further in the near term.
You catch his analysis here:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: William McDonnell has been appointed as chief financial officer of Insurance Australia Group (IAG), subject to regulatory approval. The insurance giant let the Australian Securities Exchange know about the appointment in the last 15 minutes. Mr McDonnell will be relocating to Sydney from London to take up the role. He's joining IAG from the global governance body, the Integrity Council for the Voluntary Carbon Market, where he spent two years as chief operating officer. He built that organisation from its foundation, leading it to be recognised as the world's standard-setter for carbon credits, and he oversaw the recent release of the Core Carbon Principles ad rulebook. Mr McDonnell also spent 15 years at the general insurer Royal & Sun Alliance Insurance Group, where for the last seven years he was group chief risk officer.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Insurance Australia Group to get new CFO, expert on carbon credits

He's joining IAG from the global governance body, the
Integrity Council for the Voluntary Carbon Market
, where he spent two years as chief operating officer. He built that organisation from its foundation, leading it to be recognised as the world's standard-setter for
carbon credits

image.altText: A low shot looking up at a sign on the side of Perth Children's Hospital.

items.synopsis: Charges against a teenage boy accused of raping a 13-year-old girl at Perth Children's Hospital were discontinued because of serious concerns about the safety and wellbeing of the alleged victim, it is revealed.

title.children: Charges over 13-year-old's alleged rape inside Perth Children's Hospital discontinued due to welfare concerns

image.altText: Emergency services in an Adelaide street.

items.synopsis: SA Police praises the bravery of one of its officers who entered a smoke-filled home to rescue an unconscious woman after a fire broke out at Ridgehaven in Adelaide's north-east.

title.children: Unconscious woman rescued from burning home by 'brave' young officer's 'amazing work'

image.altText: CCTV footage shows a girl being pulled unconscious from the metro train.

items.synopsis: An Iranian teenage girl is in critical condition in hospital after falling into a coma following a confrontation with agents in the Tehran metro for violating the hijab law, according to rights activists.

title.children: Iran's morality police alleged to have beaten teenage girl into coma for violating hijab law

image.altText: Skateboarder Arisa Trew is upside down, holding her skateboard as she performs a trick.

items.synopsis: Women and non-binary skaters haven't always felt welcome on the skateboarding scene, but a new crop of exciting teenage talent is breaking barriers and making waves.

title.children: The teenage girls turning skateboarding on its head
